New children's books for January 2017

Written by Jo Dixon · Published Jan 3, 2017

Picture books

Giles Andreae and Guy Parker-Rees - Be Brave Little Penguin

This picture book about Pip-Pip, the little penguin who is frightened of water, should work a charm at playgroup storytimes. Perfectly tackling the theme of overcoming fears, and featuring brilliant rhymes and absolute cuteness, we predict it will become as indispensable to the Early Years repertoire as Giraffes Can‚Äôt Dance.

Steve Antony - Thank You, Mr Panda

‚ÄúMr Panda is happy to help his friends prepare for a special surprise - if they remember to say thank you, that is!‚Äù

Could there be a better way to teach manners than with Mr Panda? I don‚Äôt think so, for with Steve Antony you get a gorgeous book full of visual style and humour too.

Jeanne Willis - I‚Äôm In Charge

‚ÄúThis romping rhyming story from award-winning author Jeanne Willis is all about a little rhino who likes to make the rules! When Rhino finds a tree bursting with fruit, he isn‚Äôt about to share it with anyone - after all, he‚Äôs in charge round here! But it looks like things are about to change.‚Äù

If your family life takes place within the forcefield of a bossy toddler, then the territory in Jeanne Willis‚Äôs latest gem should be familiar. Be grateful that your small child is human. Hers is a rhino‚Ä¶

Junior novels

Lissa Evans - Wed Wabbit

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre called Fidge and you‚Äôre nearly 11. You‚Äôve been hurled into a strange world. You have three companions: two are unbelievably weird and the third is your awful cousin Graham. You have to solve a series of nearly impossible clues. You need to deal with a cruel dictator and three thousand Wimbley Woos (yes, you read that sentence correctly). And the whole situation - the whole, entire thing - is your fault.‚Äù

Two children get trapped inside a bizarre and threatening picture book world in this exciting new adventure. It‚Äôs being hailed as a title to watch out for in 2017, funny, well written and a bit scary too. Sounds like a good one to read as a family.

Andy Griffiths and Terry Denton - The 78-storey Treehouse

‚ÄúJoin Andy and Terry in their spectacular new 78-storey treehouse. They‚Äôve added 13 new levels including a drive-thru car wash, a combining machine, a scribbletorium, an ALL-BALL sports stadium, Andyland, Terrytown, a high-security potato chip storage facility and an open-air movie theatre. Well, what are you waiting for? Come on up!‚Äù

If you haven‚Äôt climbed through the literary branches of this series yet, you MUST read the 13-, 26-, 39-, 52- and 65-storey Treehouse books before starting this new one. It‚Äôs the rules. OK? We mean it‚Ä¶

Ross Welford - What Not To Do If You Turn Invisible

‚ÄúTurning invisible at will: it‚Äôs one way of curing your acne. But far more drastic than 13-year-old Ethel Leatherhead intended when she tried a combination of untested medicines and a sunbed. It‚Äôs fun at first, being invisible. And aided by her friend Boydy, she manages to keep her extraordinary ability secret. Or does she? When one day the invisibility fails to wear off, Ethel is thrown into a nightmare of lies and deception as she struggles to keep herself safe, to find the remedy that will make her seen again - and solve the mystery of her own birth.‚Äù

Ross Welford‚Äôs first book Time Travelling with a Hamster has been nominated for several awards, so we can‚Äôt wait to read this one. It‚Äôs due out at the start of the month, so it could be just the thing to stave off that New Year boredom.

Kennilworthy Whisp and J. K. Rowling - Quidditch Through The Ages

‚ÄúThis text includes all of the information you could ever need to know about the history, the rules - and the breaking of the rules - of the noble wizarding sport of Quidditch.‚Äù

We‚Äôve ordered lots of copies of this quasi-historical analysis of the famous sport especially for HP fans, young and not quite so young. First published back in 2001, we are delighted to see it reissued. Our only regret was that it wasn‚Äôt available in time for Christmas.

YA

Sara Barnard - A Quiet Kind of Thunder

‚ÄúSteffi doesn‚Äôt talk, but she has so much to say. Rhys can‚Äôt hear, but he can listen. Their love isn‚Äôt a lightning strike, it‚Äôs the rumbling roll of thunder. Steffi has been a selective mute for most of her life - she‚Äôs been silent for so long that she feels completely invisible. But Rhys, the new boy at school, sees her. He‚Äôs deaf, and her knowledge of basic sign language means that she‚Äôs assigned to look after him. To Rhys it doesn‚Äôt matter that Steffi doesn‚Äôt talk and, as they find ways to communicate, Steffi finds that she does have a voice, and that she‚Äôs falling in love with the one person who makes her feel brave enough to use it.‚Äù

Sara Barnard‚Äôs first title, Beautiful Broken Things, caused quite a stir and featured in the first Zoella Book Club list. Her new novel A Quiet Kind of Thunder, about a girl who has chosen to be mute and a boy who can‚Äôt hear, is already being flagged up as ‚Äúone to watch for‚Äù in January.

Phil Earle - Mind The Gap

‚ÄúWhen Mikey‚Äôs dad died, something in Mikey died too. He loved his old man and he never stopped dreaming that one day his dad would land the role of a lifetime, prove them all wrong and rock back up to the estate in the flashiest car anyone had ever seen. Now there‚Äôs just numbness, and not caring, and really, really stupid decisions. He says the worst of it is that he can‚Äôt even remember his dad‚Äôs voice any more. Eventually Mikey‚Äôs best mate can‚Äôt bear it any more, and so he sets out to give Mikey the memories - and his dad‚Äôs voice - back.‚Äù

Author of the excellent Storey Street series for middle graders, Phil Earle‚Äôs new powerful YA novel is in a different league.

Jo Dixon

I work for Suffolk Libraries Stock Team.
